occurrences.line_text: Yet seeing nigh him ieopardy extreme,
Broke into open fire and rage extreme,
And threatned him with force & punishment extreme.
With extreme fury he became quite mad,
And drawing both their swords with rage extreme,
And doe dispart the hart with powre extreme,
Yet so extremely did the buffe him quell,
Extremely ioyed in so happie sight,
Extremely mad the man I surely deeme,
Was firmest fixt in mine extremest case,
And yieldes her to extremitie of time;
Did easily beleeue her strong extremitie.
At that same last extremitie full sore,
Till that prickt forth with loues extremitie,
Yet since she saw the streight extremitie,
Cryde mercie, to abate the extremitie of law.
Her sisters two Extremities:
The strong extremities of their outrage;
To proue extremities of bloudie fight,
Rather let try extremities of chaunce,
That both resolu'd the last extremities to proue.
But rather stroue extremities to way,
I will with proofe of last extremity,
Now left alone in great extremity,
And eke himselfe her cruelly exyld:
Where righteous Artegall her late exyled;
Or kept in bands, or from their loues exyled,
Like Eyas hauke vp mounts vnto the skies,
And bid them strike the marke, which he had eyde,
Their dainty parts from vew of any, which them eyde.
So saying euery Nymph full narrowly she eyde.
Gainst Britomart, and euer closely eyde
Him to commend to her, thus spake, of all well eyde.
But they were both so watchfull and well eyde,
Who missing of the marke which he had eyde,
The gray eyde Doris: all which fifty are;
And Enuie first, as she that first him eyde,
But when the Prince had once him plainely eyde,
And the sad humour loading their eye liddes,
The eye of reason was with rage yblent,
As the great eye of heauen shyned bright,
Did neuer mortall eye behold such heauenly grace.
For since mine eye your ioyous sight did mis,
Vnseemely man to please faire Ladies eye;
Did chace away sweet sleepe from sluggish eye,
Ioyous, to see his ymage in mine eye,
Where earely waite him many a gazing eye,
Does care for looke of liuing creatures eye.
At last the Paynim chaunst to cast his eye,
His suddein eye, flaming with wrathfull fyre,
Not all so satisfide, with greedie eye
Yet for to feed his fyrie lustfull eye,
And kindling coles of lust in brutish eye,
His liuing like saw neuer liuing eye,
And highly honourd in his haughtie eye,
Ne might of mortall eye be euer seene;
That eye mote not the same endure to vew.
Which when the Gyaunt spyde with staring eye,
For his eye sight him failed long ygo,
Still as he fled, his eye was backward cast,
(Said he) the which with this vnlucky eye
From highest heauen, and beares an equall eye?
As Eagles eye, that can behold the Sunne:
The fairest peece, that eye beholden can:
And euer, when his eye did her behold,
With liuing eye more faire was neuer seene,
Toung hates to tell the rest, that eye to see abhord.
Who soone as on that knight his eye did glance,
Pitifull spectacle, as euer eye did view.
And with dry drops congealed in her eye,
Then couering with a clod their closed eye,
And kindling fire at her faire burning eye,
Hath great or glorious in mortall eye.
To serue at court in view of vaunting eye;
Vnto the bush her eye did suddein glaunce,
Which mingled all with sweate, did dim his eye.
And his fraile eye with spoyle of beautie feedes;
A long the shore, as swift as glaunce of eye,
Vpon his card and compas firmes his eye,
And turned vpsidowne, to feede his eye
From the worldes eye, and from her right vsaunce?
It can puruay in twinckling of an eye;
Perdy (quoth he) yet neuer eye did vew,
So huge a masse, and hide from heauens eye?
And Shame his vgly face did hide from liuing eye.
If euer couetous hand, or lustfull eye,
As eye of man did neuer see before;
Behold, thou Faeries sonne, with mortall eye,
That liuing eye before did neuer see:
But sith thou hast found fauour in mine eye,
But rather fowler seemed to the eye;
Did not once moue, nor vpward cast his eye,
Vnto the ground she cast her modest eye,
That vew of eye could scarse him ouertake,
Which seemd so sweet and pleasant to the eye,
It selfe doth offer to his sober eye,
Still as she fled, her eye she backward threw,
Which when those knights beheld, with scornefull eye,
Eftsoones there was presented to her eye
It was not, Britomart, thy wandring eye,
That euer liuing eye I weene did see;
Saw neuer liuing eye more heauy sight,
Like neuer yet did liuing eye detect;
That like a liuely sanguine it seem'd to the eye.
Vpon her with his other blincked eye;
The fairest woman wight, that euer eye did see.
Through gracious regard of her faire eye,
But his blind eye, that syded Paridell,
But in his eye his meaning wisely red,
The whiles vnwares away her wondring eye,
That he Malbeccoes halfen eye did wyle,
His halfen eye he wiled wondrous well,
But when againe he backward cast his eye,
That he dare neuer sleepe, but that one eye
As faining to be hid from enuious eye;
And with a shaft was shot through either eye,
Tho as she backward cast her busie eye,
And euermore on daunger fixt his eye,
But still with stedfast eye and courage stout
That many of them mou'd to eye her sore.
Fond knight (sayd she) the thing that with this eye
With sting of lust, that reasons eye did blind,
When Britomart with sharpe auizefull eye
Yet was he meet, vnlesse mine eye did faine,
Which when she saw, with sodaine glauncing eye,
Where hardly eye mote see bright heauens face,
She her beholding with attentiue eye,
Should happen this with liuing eye to see,
Nor happie howre, beheld with gazefull eye,
Whilest thus I spake, behold with happy eye
Mine eye was fixt, for feare of her offence:
A sorie sight, as euer seene with eye;
He, whether mine seem'd fayrer in his eye,
Both darting forth faire beames to each mans eye,
It made her stagger oft, and stare with ghastly eye.
A while about her with confused eye;
In case she might finde fauour in his eye,
Into her eye, which th'heart mote haue relieued,
Discouered had the light to liuing eye,
Drawne with the powre of an heart-robbing eye,
And euer as she rode, her eye was backeward bent.
And with their brightnesse daz'd the straunge beholders eye.
Of all that pleasant is to eare or eye,
He also gan vplooke with drery eye,
That all about did close the compasse of his eye.
Yet would not neare approch in daungers eye,
That with the onely twinckle of her eye,
Which she beheld with lamentable eye,
The greatest shame that euer eye yet saw?
Yet dwelling in her eye, to her appeard,
On which his hungry eye was alwayes bent;
Whose like before his eye had neuer seene,
Vnder his eyebrowes looking still askaunce;
And with sterne eye-browes stared at him oft,
Sometimes him blessing with a light eye-glance,
He lowrd on her with daungerous eyeglaunce;
To them, that couet such eye-glutting gaine,
Vpon her eyelids many Graces sate,
She slept, yet twixt her eyelids closely spyde,
Vpon his heauie eye-lids chaunst to fall,
There heauie sleepe the eye-lids did surprise
This gentle crew gan from their eye-lids chace
Whose life did lie in her least eye-lids fall;
His eye-lids sad, but watcht continually,
Ne suffred slothfull sleepe her eyelids to oppresse.
And twixt the twinckling of her eye-lids bright,
Let fall her eyen, as shamefast to the earth,
While flashing beames do daze his feeble eyen,
It dimmes the dazed eyen, and daunts the senses quight.
And washed all her place with watry eyen.
All were his earthly eyen both blunt and bad,
His burning eyen, whom bloudie strakes did staine,
With loathly frogs and toades, which eyes did lacke,
And to the ground his eyes were lowly bent,
More busying his quicke eyes, her face to view,
I saw before mine eyes, if I were knowne to stray.
That my fraile eyes these lines with teares do steepe,
From her faire eyes he tooke commaundement,
To looken backe; his eyes be fixt before.
And on those guilefull dazed eyes of his
With loftie eyes, halfe loth to looke so low,
Her glorious glitterand light doth all mens eyes amaze.
And full of Argus eyes their tailes dispredden wide.
And whally eyes (the signe of gelosy,)
He clothed was, ypainted full of eyes;
His eyes did hurle forth sparkles fiery red,
And him before, I saw with bitter eyes
With stonie eyes; and all the hellish brood
That of no enuious eyes he mote be spyde:
That molten starres do drop like weeping eyes;
In their rude eyes vnworthie of so wofull plight.
Did her content to please their feeble eyes,
These eyes did see that knight both liuing and eke ded.
And all embrewd in bloud, his eyes did shine as glas.
Who when her eyes she on the Dwarf had set,
Mine eyes no more on vanitie shall feed,
The forlorne Maiden, whom your eyes haue seene
Whom these sad eyes saw nigh vnto deaths dore,
With equall eyes, their merites to restore,
His sad dull eyes deepe sunck in hollow pits,
Such as she was, their eyes might her behold,
From liuing eyes her open shame to hide,
With stony eyes, and hartlesse hollow hew,
That nought but death before his eyes he saw,
Her stedfast eyes were bent, ne swarued other way.
And opened his dull eyes, that light mote in them shine.
His blazing eyes, like two bright shining shields,
Another said, that in his eyes did rest
Another said, he saw him moue his eyes indeed.
With doubtfull eyes fast fixed on his guest;
That feeble eyes your glory may behold,
Her swollen eyes were much disfigured,
Brayes out her latest breath, and vp her eyes doth seele.
As from two weeping eyes, fresh streames do flow,
Drawing to him the eyes of all around,
As with lamenting eyes him selfe did lately vew.
Those guestes beguiled, did beguile their eyes
In her faire eyes two liuing lamps did flame,
By the hoare lockes, that hong before her eyes,
With hart then throbbing, and with watry eyes,
My hart, my hands, mine eyes, and all assayd?
Thus when she had his eyes and senses fed
Then she with liquors strong his eyes did steepe,
Your cruell eyes endure so pitteous sight,
His face with smoke was tand, and eyes were bleard,
Thereat with staring eyes fixed askaunce,
Did feed his eyes, and fild his inner thought.
Another blis before mine eyes I place,
Their staring eyes sparckling with feruent fire,
And his slow eyes beguiled of their sight,
Staring with hollow eyes, and stiffe vpstanding heares.
That they encombred all mens eares and eyes,
Bent hollow beetle browes, sharpe staring eyes,
And euery one of them had Lynces eyes,
That is each thing, by which the eyes may fault:
And th'amarous sweet spoiles to greedy eyes reuele.
He much rebukt those wandring eyes of his,
With her false eyes fast fixed in his sight,
And through his humid eyes did sucke his spright,
And her faire eyes sweet smyling in delight,
And with ambrosiall kisses bathe his eyes;
Her wanton eyes, ill signes of womanhed,
Of her false eyes, that at her hart did ayme,
Late dayes ensample, which these eyes beheld,
That the dim eyes of my deare Marinell
In whose faire eyes, like lamps of quenched fire,
Besides all hope with melting eyes did vew,
And groning inly deepe, at last his eyes,
His watry eyes, drizling like deawy raine,
From her faire eyes and gracious countenaunce.
Wiping the teares from her suffused eyes,
Her firie eyes with furious sparkes did stare,
In stead of eyes two burning lampes she set
To stirre and roll them, like a womans eyes;
But his deceiptfull eyes did neuer lin,
And blubbred face with teares of her faire eyes:
These eyes did see, that they will euer rew
It is not yron bandes, nor hundred eyes,
Past through his eyes, and secretly did glyde
Vnto their wils, and one eyes watch escape;
Two eyes him needeth, for to watch and wake,
And Hellenors both eyes did eke beguyle,
Both eyes and hart attonce, during the whyle
And with pale eyes fast fixed on the rest,
With vpstart haire, and staring eyes dismay,
More eath to number, with how many eyes
Her greedy eyes with gazing a long space:
Her heauy eyes with natures burdein deare,
He lookt askew with his mistrustfull eyes,
His rolling eyes did neuer rest in place,
His blindfold eyes he bad a while vnbind,
With squinted eyes contrarie wayes intended,
And all mens eyes and hearts, which there among
Of gold, that bad eyes might it not prophane:
The eyes of all, allur'd with close delight,
That daz'd the eyes of all, as with exceeding light.
With hollow eyes and rawbone cheekes forspent,
When gentle sleepe his heauie eyes would close;
From her faire eyes wiping the deawy wet,
For from his fearefull eyes two fierie beames,
From powrefull eyes close venim doth conuay
And what he was, whose eyes did flame with fire;
From his false eyes, into their harts and parts entire.
To see the sight perforce, that both her eyes were loth.
And euermore his eyes about him went,
False Labyrinthes, fond runners eyes to daze;
For stedfast still her eyes did fixed rest,
Ne euer durst her eyes from ground vpreare,
Whose eyes like twinkling stars in euening cleare,
And through her eyes like sudden lightning flashed,
But if the least appear'd, her eyes she streight reprieued.
Ye guilty eyes (sayd she) the which with guyle
And with sweete rest her heauy eyes did close,
Vpon the earth, with hollow eyes deepe pent,
To turne her eyes from his intent away:
Approuing dayly to their noble eyes
That any yron eyes to see it would agrize.
Lookt vp with eyes full sad and hart full sore;
With her dull eyes did seeme to looke askew,
The eyes of all, which thereon fixed beene;
And in the eyes of men great liking find;
And both the eyes did steale the hart away.
An hart, not carried with too curious eyes,
Long fed his greedie eyes with the faire sight
Gan reare her eyes as to the chearefull light,
These eyes him saw vpon the cold earth sprad,
And far from enuious eyes that mote him spight.
From his soft eyes the teares he wypt away,
He bad his eyes to be vnblindfold both,
Some with their eyes the daintest morsels chose;
Now being naked, to their sordid eyes
Which mote not be prophan'd of common eyes,
That euen he him selfe his eyes enuyde,
With which his eyes mote haue deluded beene.
With lustfull eyes, beheld that louely guest,
These marchants fixed eyes did so amaze,
With cloud of death vpon her eyes displayd;
And vp to heauen his eyes fast streming threw.
These eyes saw die, and dearely did lament:
For on her brest I with these eyes did vew
Besmeard with smoke that nigh his eye-sight blent;
Or euer sleepe his eye-strings did vntye,
For Guyons lookes, but scornefull eyglaunce at him shot.
Her out of carelesse swowne. Her eylids blew
A while his heauie eylids couer'd haue,
Shed thy faire beames into my feeble eyne,
And eke with fatnesse swollen were his eyne,
And hid his face; through which his hollow eyne
To haue returnd, but dazed were his eyne,
So flam'd his eyne with rage and rancorous yre:
With that adowne out of her Christall eyne
His feeble eyne, with too much brightnesse dazed,
And mourn'd to see her losse before her eyne,
With many bitter teares shed from his blubbred eyne.
With heauie eyne, from teares vneath refrayning,
But shedding few soft teares from tender eyne,
And sparkling fire out of his furious eyne,
With drearie drouping eyne lookt vp like one aghast.
Whom whylest she did with watrie eyne behold,
Eyther for th'euill, which he did therein,
Lo there before his face his Lady is,
More busying his quicke eyes, her face to view,
And a dull blast, that breathing on her face,
And laid her stole aside. Her angels face
Face of faire Ladie she before did vew,
Wherein her face she often vewed fayne,
That Phoebus chearefull face durst neuer vew,
In hart, and chaunge in that great mothers face:
The wicked witch, saying; In that faire face
At her abhorred face, so filthy and so fowle.
He snatcht the vele, that hong her face before;
His blushing face in foggy cloud implyes,
With ruffled rayments, and faire blubbred face,
Flocke all about to see her louely face:
And face all tand with scorching sunny ray,
Henceforth thy hated face for euer hyde,
That Phoebus golden face it did attaint,
As when her face is staynd with magicke arts constraint.
So backward still was turnd his wrincled face,
Both feet and face one way are wont to lead.
Since I the heauens chearefull face did vew,
Such is the face of falshood, such the sight
She flying fast from heauens hated face,
From that day forth I lou'd that face diuine;
Ne bring him forth in face of dreadfull fight,
Nor drop of bloud in all his face appeares
For leuer had I die, then see his deadly face.
And hid his face; through which his hollow eyne
And troubled bloud through his pale face was seene
Like sunny beames threw from her Christall face,
Whose face he made, all beasts to feare, and gaue
In face of iudgement he their right would plead,
The scorching flame sore swinged all his face,
His fierie face in billowes of the west,
Out of the sea faire Titans deawy face,
The face of earth, and wayes of liuing wight,
To see the face of that victorious man:
And glorious light of her sunshyny face
In this faire mirrhour maist behold thy face,
And her faire face with teares was fowly blubbered.
And scratcht her face with ghastly dreriment,
To see faire heauens face, and life not leaue,
the face of golden Meane.
And in her face faire peace, and mercy doth appeare.
Now hath faire Phoebe with her siluer face
Her face so faire as flesh it seemed not,
How shall fraile pen descriue her heauenly face,
Both feare and hope he in her face did find,
For neither doth thy face terrestriall shew,
And eke her face ill fauourd, full of wrinckles old.
And bruze with clownish fistes his manly face:
Did shew his face, my selfe I did esteeme,
In Claribellaes clothes. Her proper face
And darksom dens, where Titan his face neuer shewes.
His face with smoke was tand, and eyes were bleard,
And Shame his vgly face did hide from liuing eye.
Her face right wondrous faire did seeme to bee,
Like Phoebus face adornd with sunny rayes,
In whose dead face he red great magnanimity.
I long haue lackt, I ioy thy face to vew;
That euen heauen reioyced her sweete face to see.
Held downe her head, the whiles her louely face
And turnd his face away; but she the same
Through his faire daughters face, & flattring word;
And in his flight the villein turn'd his face,
His fearefull face in time of greatest storme,
And heauens chearefull face enueloped,
His deawy face out of the sea doth reare:
Nought but her louely face she for his looking left.
Them to behold, and in his sparkling face
Yet sleeping, in his well proportiond face,
Whose face did seeme as cleare as Christall stone,
To get a snatch, when turned is his face.
Flasht through her face, as it had been a flake
His manly face, that did his foes agrize,
Lookt foorth, as Phoebus face out of the east,
His face, was with the loue thereof beguild;
His ioyous face did to the world reueale,
Come daughter come, come; spit vpon my face,
The face of heauen, and the cleare aire engrost,
That neither bloud in face, nor life in hart
For he is faire and fresh in face and guize,
And scratcht his face, and with his teeth did teare
And louely face, made fit for to deceiue
Once hauing turnd, no more returnd his face,
To looke on her faire face, and marke her snowy skin.
And blubbred face with teares of her faire eyes:
Downe in her lap she hid her face, and loudly shright.
On her faire face so did he feede his fill,
Consume his hart, and scorch his Idoles face,
Daunst liuely, and her face did with a Lawrell shade.
His face vpon the ground did groueling ly,
On foot, vpon the face of liuing land?
Her ample shield she threw before her face,
His face was rugged, and his hoarie hed
Yet his owne face was dreadfull, ne did need
Holding a lattice still before his face,
Had deathes owne image figurd in her face,
But Ladies none they were, albee in face
Her face most fowle and filthy was to see,
Thereof did in his frouning face appeare:
Seest not the Ladie there before thy face?
Thereto she was right faire, when so her face
The face of his deare Canacee vnheale;
To tell the feature of each goodly face.
Whose face discouered, plainely did expresse
Full blacke and griesly did his face appeare,
That in his face, as in a looking glasse,
He sees her face; doth fall in loue,
With that her angels face, vnseene afore,
Beheld the louely face of Artegall,
Ne in his face or bloud or life appeard,
But turnd her face, and fled away for euermore.
Where hardly eye mote see bright heauens face,
That in short time his face they ouergrew,
With heary glib deform'd, and meiger face,
Tho soone as day discouered heauens face
That would haue maz'd a man his dreadfull face to vew.
And rent his haire and scratcht his face for paine.
Deceiued through great likenesse of their face.
His name was Doubt, that had a double face,
Of his grim face, were from approaching scard;
And turn'd his face away, as he did stand,
Like to the Morne, when first her shyning face
And euermore vpon the Goddesse face
Who soone as he beheld that angels face,
The sunne at length his ioyous face doth cleare:
A great increase in her faire blushing face;
And all his face deform'd with infamie,
His face was couered, and his head was bar'd,
But when as he discouered had her face,
And dare euen deathes most dreadfull face behold?
As she her face had wypt, to fresh her blood:
That she the face of her new foe might see.
One of those two, and force him turne his face;
For he so crafty was to forge and face,
That could deceiue one looking in his face;
Yet did appeare rare beautie in her face,
The cursed Ate, brought her face to face,
The cursed Ate, brought her face to face,
Euen foule Adulterie her face before,
For of a Mayd she had the outward face,
His chearefull face, and light to men restore,
Thereon distill, and deaw her daintie face,
His face was vgly, and his countenance sterne,
Her face was vgly, and her mouth distort,
Yet seuenteene yeares, but tall and faire of face
Seeing his face so louely sterne and coy,
That in thy face appeares and gratious goodlyhead.
Did shut the gate against him in his face,
And from his face the filth that did it ray,
This litle babe, of sweete and louely face,
Did front him face to face against him bent,
Did front him face to face against him bent,
Yet did her face and former parts professe
To her the Gods, for her so dreadfull face,
And praise the feature of her goodly face,
They made amongst them selues; but when her face
And soothly sure she was full fayre of face,
That he his face, his head, his brest did beat,
